headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call this morning. The results corresponding to our second fiscal quarter were stronger than expected during this very turbulent time. Low oil prices continue to depress de
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call this morning. The results corresponding to our second fiscal quarter were stronger than expected during this very turbulent time. Low oil prices continue to depress demand levels for drilling services during the transition into our third fiscal quarter. Even with the oil prices rebounding from the lows reached earlier this year, our customers have continued to release rigs, albeit at a slower pace. Although there appears to be some stabilization in the oil macro outlook, there are still uncertainty in the market, and our customers remain cautious. 
The industry rig count decline has been more swift and severe than we expected at the time of our last earnings call in late January. And we reviewed at that time as being more barish than most. While we don't believe we have reached the absolute bottom yet, we believe their indications of trough is nearing. Several industry analysts have predicted a trough count ranging from 850 to 750 rigs in the U.S. land market, and we believe that is a reasonable fairly given today's oil price environment and the discussions we have had with customers. 
We have commented that rig count reductions have been indiscriminate, and that trend continues. We are even in an development where our customers are releasing rigs based upon their liquidity as well as economic considerations. In many cases, regardless of the rig's performance, we estimate that approximately 40% of the sideline rigs are mechanical rigs and that approximately 31% are SCR rigs, while AC drive rigs makeup approximately 29%. 
Despite the reductions in our activity, there maybe another sign that the market is establishing a bottom. We have recently contracted a handful of FlexRigs in the spot markets to customers who are trading off, hydrating rigs and their drilling programs. 
Horizontal well complexity and factory-type drilling requirements in the ongoing U.S. energy revolution have changed the game for drilling contractors and other service providers. As a result, fewer mechanical and SCR rigs will be required in the future, especially in the rig category below 2,000 horsepower drill works rating. 
This morning, we announced the decommissioning of our first and second generation FlexRigs. These 17 SCR-powered rigs built in 1998 and 2001, were a very important strategic move in the company's history. The belief was that our customers would be willing to pay a higher day rate for a safer and more efficient rig than the success of that strategy led to H&P's investment at AC drive FlexRigs. And I'll talk more about that in a moment. 
Even though the Flex 1 and Flex 2 rigs were a dramatic improvement over the legacy rig fleet, it has become evident, SCR-powered is the preferred technology for today's more complex well designs, while customers want is a AC drive technology. 
Now back to designing and building the first AC drive FlexRig, where we began with a clean sheet of paper and safety by design rig structures and power the design with AC drive technology. The value proposition to our customers was compelling, and the market finally embraced our efforts. We recognized a long time ago that eventually other contractors would builds AC rigs to compete with H&P. We often get the question, "Are you concerned about your peers' new AC drive rigs?" We answer that by saying, "Our strategy has remained focused. Build the best rigs, employ the best people and create support systems and processes that continue to deliver the FlexRig value proposition to our customers." 
The future holds many opportunities for H&P with FlexRig3, FlexRig4 and FlexRig5 makeup approximately 37% of the AC drive market share in the U.S. today, and FlexRig have an opportunity to take market share internationally as well. 
Before turning the call back to the Juan Pablo, let me mention a key element of our company culture. Our focus on continuous improvement and building a learning organization is a key advantage in both the highs and lows of the energy cycle. I am proud of what our people accomplished in 2014 for our customers, where we drilled 71 million fit of wellbore and operated over 325 rigs at the peak of activity in October of last year. 
In addition to setting records for footage and rig activity, our people continue to work on innovating technology solutions, safety, systems, cost control, systems and processes that position the company to be better prepared today than ever before, and certainly, better than we were then in 2009 downturn. 
The organization's response to this very severe reduction in rig count has been significant. Our field operations to date have idled over 150 rigs, taking care to preserve the rig and equipment integrity so we are ready to respond when the market improves. I believe our experienced leadership team provides us with an advantage to manage through the current downturn even more efficiently and effectively than during previous cycles. 
And let me close by saying, equally important to the tactical side of our business, is our continued strategic focus on our good effectiveness during this difficult times. We will continue to invest in systems and processes, which will allow us to efficiently scale operations to meet changing industry conditions and be prepared with our significant AC fleet capability to respond quickly to future demand levels. We believe this makes H&P the best position drilling contractor in the industry today. 
Now I'll turn the call to Juan Pablo, and he will give you more details on the second fiscal quarter and outlook for our next quarter. Juan Pablo?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The company percentage $150 million in net income, $227 million in operating income and $883 million in revenues during the second quarter of fiscal 2015. During this deep downturn that the industry is experiencing, these quarterly levels
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The company percentage $150 million in net income, $227 million in operating income and $883 million in revenues during the second quarter of fiscal 2015. During this deep downturn that the industry is experiencing, these quarterly levels were down significantly as compared to the prior quarter and are expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter. 
Following are some comments on each of our drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling operations delivered approximately $225 million in segment operating income during the second fiscal quarter. As expected, the number of quarterly revenue base today significantly declined, resulting in an average of approximately 231 active rigs during the second fiscal quarter, representing a 24% decline in revenue days as compared to the first fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 158 of these rigs were under term contract and approximately 73 rigs work in the spot market. 
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day decreased about 3.6% to $27,575, and the average rig expense today increased by 2.7% to $13,395, resulting in an average rig margin per day of $14,190. 
During the quarter, the segment generated approximately $71 million in revenues corresponding to long-term contract early terminations. Given existing notifications for early terminations, we expect to generate over $75 million during the third fiscal quarter and over $30 million after that in early termination revenues. 
Since November of last year, we have received termination notices for a total of 44 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment. 
Total early termination revenues related to these 44 contracts are now estimated at approximately $204 million. Approximately 90 of which corresponds to cash flow previously expected to be generated through normal operations during fiscal 2015, $65 million during fiscal 2016 and $49 million after that. 
As of today, the 336 available rigs in the U.S. land segment, include approximately 165 AC drive FlexRigs generating revenue, and 171 idle rigs, including 163 idle AC drive FlexRigs. 
Included in the 165 rigs generating revenue, our 138 rigs under term contract and 27 rigs in the spot market. The 165 rigs generating revenue include rigs that are on standby-type day rate, and some new build deliveries that have been delayed in exchange for compensation from customers. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter of fiscal 2015, we expect revenue days to degrees by about 32% quarter-to-quarter, and that given the current trend, we could have approximately 150 rigs or less generating revenue days by the end of the quarter. 
Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to decline to roughly $27,000. The average rig expense per day is expected at roughly $13,600. 
Subject to additional early terminations and excluding rigs that we have received early termination notifications for, the segment already have term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 130 rigs during the third fiscal quarter, an average of about 117 rigs during the fourth fiscal quarter and an average of about 107 rigs and 79 rigs during fiscal 2016 and fiscal 2017 respectively. 
The average rig margin per day levels for these rigs that are already under term contract is expected to remain strong and roughly flat during the next several quarters, as some rigs roll-off and new builds are deployed. 
The pricing for rigs in the spot market declined by approximately 15% from the first to the second quarter of fiscal 2015. And is expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter. Spot pricing today is about 23% lower as compared to spot pricing at the peak last November. 
Let me now transitions to our offshore segment. Segment operating income declined to approximately  $19 million from $21 million during the prior quarter. Total revenue days decreased by about 2%, as 1 rig was demobilized and became idle during the second fiscal quarter. 
The average rig margin per day declined by about 10% to $18,671 during the second fiscal quarter, as 1 rig that continues generate revenue while stacked on the customer's platform, had a significant day rate and margin reduction. 8 of the company's 9 offshore platform rigs continue to generate revenue days by the end of the second fiscal quarter. 
As we look at the third quarter of fiscal 2015, we expect revenue days to decline by about 10%, as one of the 8 rigs generating revenue completes its current project is demobilized and becomes idle during the quarter. We also expect the average rig margin per day to decline to approximately $12,000 during the quarter. The expected average margin decline is mostly attributable to 3 rigs that are generating revenue days during the third fiscal partner, but that are now expected to be idle on the corresponding customer offshore platforms with new day rates and margins that are significantly lower as compared to regular operating the rates and margins. 
The total of 7 of the company's 9 offshore platform rigs are now expected to be generating revenue days at the end of the third fiscal quarter. 
Management contracts on platform rigs continued to favorably contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contributions during the second fiscal quarter was approximately $8 million and is expected to decline to approximately $6 million during the third fiscal quarter. 
Moving on to our international land operations. Segment operating income decreased to approximately $6 million during the quarter. Excluding the impact of $373 per day corresponding to nearly contract termination revenues, the average rig margin per day slightly decreased to $10,524. As expected, quarterly revenue days decreased by about 11% to a an equivalent of slightly over 20 active rigs. 
As of today, our international land segment has 21 active rigs, including 12 in Argentina, 4 in Colombia, 2 in the UAE, 2 in Ecuador and 1 in Bahrain. 17 rigs are idle, including 3 that are under contract but no longer active. These 17 rigs include 5 in Argentina, 4 in Ecuador, 4 in Colombia, 2 in Bahrain and 2 in Tunisia. An additional 2 rigs are mobilizing to fill locations in Argentina.
For the third fiscal quarter, we expect international land quarterly revenue days to be flat, potentially increasing up to 5%. We expect the average rig margin per day to decline by about 15% to 20% as compared to the second fiscal quarter, excluding any impact from early contract terminations. We expect to generate early termination revenues in this segment of approximately $9 million during the third fiscal quarter and another $9 million during the fourth fiscal quarter, that corresponding to 2 rigs that are under contract but no longer active.
The expected daily margin decline in the segment is primarily due to rigs that are in transition and others becoming idle. We expect to see all 10 of the YPF project rigs generating revenue days during the fourth fiscal quarter. 
Let me now comment on corporate level details. Our liquidity position is very long. We recently issued 10-year unsecured notes for $500 million, with 4.65% coupons and a 4.723% yield. Our capital expenditures estimates for fiscal 2015 remains at approximately $1.3 billion, about 70% of which corresponds to the funding of our continued organic growth under the sponsorship of attractive long-term contracts with customers. Our fiscal 2015 construction cadence remains unchanged, but we are reducing our fiscal 2016 cadence to 1 FlexRig per month beginning in October through March ,which allows us to have greater new builds continuity as we go through this downturn, while at the same time, not impacting the corresponding value of our backlog. 
Including the long-term contracts for the 40 new FlexRigs scheduled to be delivered during all of fiscal 2015 and the additional 6 rigs scheduled for fiscal 2016, we have secured term contracts for an average of approximately 148 rigs across our 3 drilling segments during the third fiscal quarter, and approximately 134 rigs during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2015. In addition, an average of about 121 rigs is already under contract during fiscal 2016, and an average of approximately 93 rigs during fiscal 2017.
The term contract coverage just mentioned excludes long-term contracts for which we have received early contract termination notifications. Given that these early terminations allow us to remain whole in terms of our expected cash flow from the corresponding operations, their impact on both our earnings and liquidity should be favorable as this accelerates the expected payback on our investments. 
Given the trends in market conditions, our backlog decreased from approximately $4.6 billion as of December 31, 2014, to approximately $3.9 billion as of March 31, 2015. The value of our backlog is expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter as we earn related income through operations or through early contract terminations. 
We expect our total annual depreciation expense to be approximately $600 million during fiscal 2015, and our general and administrative expenses to be approximately $140 million. Interest expense after capitalized interest is expected to be approximately $15 million for fiscal 2015, and the effective tax rate for the remaining 2 quarters of fiscal 2015 is expected to be between 34% and 35%. Our deferred income tax liability as of March 31, 2015 was approximately $1.32 billion. 
At this point, we expect this liability to remain in the range of $1.3 billion and $1.4 billion through at least the end of fiscal 2017.
With that, let me turn the call back to John.

componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo. Before opening the call to questions, I want to reiterate a few key points. As we managed through the current decline in activity, our fleet size provides us with a distinct advantage. With the largest AC drive fleet available in the industry today, the company has unprecedented leverage to significantly increase activity levels during the future industry recovery and ongoing replacement cycle. 
In addition to our fleet advantage, H&P has over 1,600 rig years of AC drive experience. This experience provides the foundation to deliver superior value to our customers by providing innovative solutions and safer, more productive operations. We expect these efforts, along with the company's demonstrated capital discipline, to continue to result in pricing, margin and return on investment premiums that allow us to create value for our shareholders. 
And now we will open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, Kurt, this is John. The Flex 1s and 2s, and I think you recognized this I'd say the Flex 1s and 2s were SCR rigs. They were also rigs that we didn't design the structures on the rig. They were through the kind of traditional sourcing in the marketpl
componenttext: Well, Kurt, this is John. The Flex 1s and 2s, and I think you recognized this I'd say the Flex 1s and 2s were SCR rigs. They were also rigs that we didn't design the structures on the rig. They were through the kind of traditional sourcing in the marketplace. Those rigs haven't worked really in the last couple of years. We have had some different opportunities to potentially sell those rigs. But really, the Flex 3s, 4s and 5s,  the Flex 3s that we built in 2002 to 2004, if you will recall the first 32 we built, those rigs have continue to work their spot in term and they've been in a situation where they typically commanded the same type of revenues and margins that we've seen with our newer Flex 3. Some have skid systems and some don't. It's kind of a mixed bag. But I feel real good about where we are in terms of drilling with those rigs going forward. We don't have, I just wanted to remind you, too, we do have 8 3,000 horsepower SCR rigs, one of which we work at the end of last year on the [indiscernible] project, deep gas project in South Louisiana. We'll continue to have those rigs. We have 2,000, 3,000 horsepower SCR rigs working in South America. And then, of course, we have our first 3,000 horsepower AC rig also working in South America, working in Colombia. So I feel good about where we are. And I think those rigs that we continue to upgrade those rigs over time and just about every way possible. They continue to deliver great value for customers, and I feel good about where we are with those rigs.

componenttext: Well, clearly, today is a different market than what we saw in 2012 and 2013. Today is obviously a lot more similar to what downturn at the end of '08 and going into '09, first part of 2010. Of course, as you said, I think we have 15% on the active fleet at the peak in '08, that was AC drive. So it is going to be a different environment. It's hard to say exactly where pricing will be. I think our expectation would be in the spot market, similar to what we saw in '09 were in the high teens range. The rates that we're going to be competing against still be some head-to-head competition with AC on AC. But you still have a significant number of SCR and mechanical rigs that are out working to day, drilling unconventional resource plays. But really our design to adequately address the challenges and delivered to tough cycle times that AC rig can deliver.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Angie, I think we've done -- this isn't the first significant downturn we've been through. I just mentioned the '08, '09 downturn, and we responded coming out of that very well. I think our peak rig count in '08 was about 185, and we got down to a l
componenttext: Well, Angie, I think we've done -- this isn't the first significant downturn we've been through. I just mentioned the '08, '09 downturn, and we responded coming out of that very well. I think our peak rig count in '08 was about 185, and we got down to a little over 100 rigs. And, of course, this time, bigot close to 300 rigs working in the U.S. and we're down to 160. Our experience is that the rigs go back to work. We have a lot of experienced, skilled personnel of the rigs that are working and, in a lot of cases, lower positions, so those guys are always eager to move up into that next role, that next lot. And I personally don't think it's going to be a challenge. The other advantage that we have in our business, of course, is that when you compare the earnings that a guy can have working a year in the oilfields compared to building houses or other types of competitive jobs, there's really not a great comparison. And so I think people are typically eager to come back. And I think we've H&P specifically, we could have created a lots of job opportunities and upward mobility, and our guys have seen that through the cycles. We've grown more quickly than our peers. And when we have that kind of growth, we promote from within, and those guys have opportunities to move up in the organization. So that's a long-winded answer to your question, but I don't think we're going to have a challenge personally.

componenttext: That's very helpful. And then, Juan Pablo, this question for you, and in fact, the question asked to me. So given the current market environment, how much of a focus is the dividend, the commitment to the dividend going forward? Obviously, you have more liquidity. You just did that offering. So just your thoughts and comments there, and your thoughts going forward.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Angie. We've said in the past that every time the company looks at the possibility of increasing dividends as we have, of course, over the last few years, especially the sustainability of that dollar per share amount is a very important consideratio
componenttext: Sure, Angie. We've said in the past that every time the company looks at the possibility of increasing dividends as we have, of course, over the last few years, especially the sustainability of that dollar per share amount is a very important consideration. And we look at different scenarios and stress cases to determine whether or not we feel comfortable with the sustainability of those new levels. And we certainly do feel comfortable and continue to feel comfortable that we will be in good position to continue to pay those dividends for the foreseeable future. And potentially, hopefully, as the industry and the market recovers, we might have a situation where we, once again, increase it. Of course, there may be situations in the mid- to long term that are unexpected, that may be extreme, that may represent a structural change in the business that we might have to look at and determine whether at that point there may be a change. But as far as we can see, we are very comfortable with the sustainability and our commitment today.

componenttext: Yes, Robin. The rigs that we have replaced are, in some cases, legacy rigs. In other case, I think they're -- in one of the cases, it was kind of a lower end performing AC rate. And the day rates that we received, I know in the legacy case, it was a higher rates, I was assuming it was on the other rigs. So they were high teens type rigs that we've talked about. The value proposition is clearly there. I mean, you've seen our value proposition side that we've shown for years that we're saving 10%, 15%, 20% on a well. We have a higher day rate and we're able to save the customer money as well as deliver more wells in a given year by working that things. So our belief continues to be that there will be a replacement cycle -- a replacement cycle will continue. However, again, I stated, too, just a handful of rigs, unfortunately, we still have more rigs that are coming other than rigs that we're putting that into the market. But at least it is an encouraging sign that we haven't seen in a couple of months, anyway.

componenttextpreview: That would be our expectation, Robin. I think the AC drive market share today in the current active fleet is approximately 54%. So it's up slightly from what you quoted from the previous presentation. I think it will probably continue to increase. And tha
componenttext: That would be our expectation, Robin. I think the AC drive market share today in the current active fleet is approximately 54%. So it's up slightly from what you quoted from the previous presentation. I think it will probably continue to increase. And that you'll see over time, of course, is that as older --  because there are some older rigs, legacy rigs and then underperforming rigs that are under term contract that as they roll off, there's possibility that those rigs could be high graded. So that would be our expectation. That's what we saw in 2009 and 2010. Our customers, operators in general, looking for opportunities. The other advantage of this type of the market is the ability to attract new customers. In 2009 and 2010, we were able to attract a lot of new customers to H&P because we didn't have to sign a 3-year term contract, they didn't have to wait in line. They were able to grab an available FlexRig and put it to work and test drive it and see how it worked out. Another data point is in the horizontal and directional market, AC rigs have approximately 59% market share. So again, you can just see that there is another large percentage of rigs that are mechanical and SCR that are drilling horizontal and directional that are drilling some pretty challenging complex wells. So that offers a great upside for us.

componenttext: Kind of want to stick to this value proposition, and looking with the longer term. But, John, is there a scenario where maybe some less competitive rigs stick around because operators choose them, because, on price, for example, if those rigs are going for $12,000 a day and an AC type rig is going to $18,000 to $20,000 a day, is that $6,000 gap there in the day rate, is that enough to sway an operator to stick with the less competitive rig? Do you have a sense of that?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Dave, our experience would tell us that if the operator is sticking with that lower tier rig, they're giving up some value because, again, we've heard this from many customers, or pardoned, many competitors over the years that as we began to get the
componenttext: Well, Dave, our experience would tell us that if the operator is sticking with that lower tier rig, they're giving up some value because, again, we've heard this from many customers, or pardoned, many competitors over the years that as we began to get the picture of what they needed a more advanced rig to compete in the market place, oftentimes, they would say, and these were leader within in their organization would say, "We can't charge a rate low enough that is compelling for an operator to pick that rig up because of the value proposition." So we believe that it's clear that it's of there. It doesn't mean that we're implying that there won't ever be or there won't be mechanical and SCR rigs working in the future. I think that there will be. But I do think it's going to be a fewer number. We've talked about it on our last call, you can go back and review the notes, I'm not going to try to recap it, but with each successive peak and trough, it was each successive cycle you see fewer and fewer mechanical and SCR rigs going back to 2005. And that trend will continue. One of the components in addition to customers that's important, and I didn't touched on this earlier when Angie asked a question about people, and that is the new rigs, AC drive FlexRigs, are so much better to work on, they're safer, they're more environmentally conducive to working on this just an easier work environment. And that has a real attraction to people. So you're going to  get the best people that are working on the new rigs, puts a lot of pressure on rigs that were designed in 70 -- 60, 70s and 80s.

componenttextpreview: Well, Scott this is John. Thank goodness, I don't get paid to make predictions on oil and gas prices. Our senses is, like we talked about in our opening comments, our sense is it feels like we're finding a floor. As you know, there are so many variables i
componenttext: Well, Scott this is John. Thank goodness, I don't get paid to make predictions on oil and gas prices. Our senses is, like we talked about in our opening comments, our sense is it feels like we're finding a floor. As you know, there are so many variables involved and things that are unexpected that could happen, which is why I think, again, we continue to see our customers being cautious. But you're right, we said, we talked about on our last call that markets work, and eventually they work and oil prices have a tendency to overshoot on the high side, on the low side. There's a lot of forces working out there that could potentially contribute to exactly what you said. And so I think your reasoning is right on target, it's just a very difficult situation to try to call it. I think there are a lot of people out there now that seem to be leaning more towards the second half of the year, in the first part of 2016 and starting to see some improvement. And so I think that's a reasonable assumption. But I sure don't want to try to call it.

componenttext: Scott, we've talked about that. Talked a lot of about it over time. And I think at least for H&P, it would be somewhat dilutive for us to go out and acquire a competitor. And again, we thought through it, whether it's a small competitor or large. In any event, it ends up having a dilutive effect. We would prefer to continue to grow the company organically. We see some real synergies associated with having the fleet that we have, and that's part of what we're speaking to as we talk about processes and systems as we move forward. But does it make sense from an industry perspective? I think it does. I think there's probably some logical combinations out there. I don't know. Who would be? But I'm sure there's some logical opportunities.

componenttext: Brad, I think you've heard us, you probably heard us, before we talk about in the last call that there really isn't that really hasn't been a spot market per se. We're starting to see a little bit of a spot market develop now. I mean, obviously, it's going to come down to competitors deciding at what level they're going to price rigs at. I think for us right now, we're down, I think Juan Pablo said we're down 23% spot pricing. To remind you, in '09, 2009, spot pricing was down approximately 30% from the peak. So we've kind of thought that 30% was a reasonable type of an estimate. I'm not --  I don't think we can call a bottom or in a spot market pricing at this stage because I think we're still really early on developing the spot market. However, I will say, I think, an interesting point to keep in mind is that while we have 30% market share on the AC, our next 3 largest peers have approximately 38%. So 75% is a market share of AC is by 4 contractors and then there's approximately 20 that make up the other 25%. So it's a relatively small group of competitors out there, and so you would think there would be some pricing discipline. I know I've heard some of our larger peers talk about that and being willing to depend a certain level of pricing. So that would be our expectations going forward. But it's -- I don't think we're in a position where we can call the trough on spot market pricing.

Thank you, and welcome, everyone, to Helmerich & Payne's Conference Call and Webcast Corresponding to the Second Quarter of Fiscal 2015. The speakers today will be John Lindsay, President and CEO; and me, Juan Pablo Tardio, Vice President and CFO. Also with us today is Dave Hardy, Manager of Investor Relations. 
As usual, and as defined by the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, all forward-looking statements made during this call are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties as discussed in the company's annual report on forms 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The company's actual results may differ materially from those indicated or implied by such forward-looking statements. 
We will also be making reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as segment operating income and operating statistics. You may find the GAAP reconciliation comments and calculations on the last page of today's press release. 
I will now turn the call over to John Lindsay.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call this morning. The results corresponding to our second fiscal quarter were stronger than expected during this very turbulent time. Low oil prices continue to depress
componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on the call this morning. 
The results corresponding to our second fiscal quarter were stronger than expected during this very turbulent time. Low oil prices continue to depress demand levels for drilling services during the transition into our third fiscal quarter. Even with oil prices rebounding from the lows reached earlier this year, our customers have continued to re-lease rigs, albeit at a slower pace. Although there appears to be some stabilization in the oil macro outlook, there are still uncertainty in the market, and our customers remain cautious. 
The industry rig count decline has been more swift and severe than we expected at the time of our last earnings call in late January. And we reviewed at that time as being more bearish than most. While we don't believe we have reached the absolute bottom yet, we do believe there are indications that the trough is nearing. Several industry analysts have predicted a trough count ranging from 850 to 750 rigs in the U.S. land market, and we believe that is a reasonable fairly given today's oil price environment and the discussions we have had with customers. 
We have commented that rig count reductions have been indiscriminate, and that trend continues. Yet even in an development where customers are re-leasing rigs based upon their liquidity as well as economic considerations, in many cases regardless of the rig's performance, we estimate that approximately 40% of the sideline rigs are mechanical rigs and that approximately 31% are SCR rigs, while AC drive rigs makeup approximately 29%. 
Despite the reductions in our activity, there may be another sign that the market is establishing a bottom. We have recently contracted a handful of FlexRigs in the spot market to customers who are trading up hydrating rigs in their drilling programs. 
Horizontal well complexity and factory-type drilling requirements in the ongoing U.S. energy revolution have changed the game for drilling contractors and other service providers. As a result, fewer mechanical and SCR rigs will be required in the future, especially in the rig categories below 2,000 horsepower drawworks rating. 
This morning, we announced the decommissioning of our first and second generation FlexRigs. These 17 SCR-powered rigs built in 1998 and 2001 were a very important strategic move in the company's history. The belief was that our customers would be willing to pay a higher day rate for a safer and more efficient rig, and the success of that strategy led to H&P's investment in AC drive FlexRigs. And I'll talk more about that in a moment. 
Even though the Flex 1 and Flex 2 rigs were a dramatic improvement over the legacy rig fleet, it has become evident SCR power isn't the preferred technology for today's more complex well designs. What customers want is AC drive technology. 
Now back to designing and building the first AC drive FlexRig, where we began with a clean sheet of paper and safety by design rig structures and power the design with AC drive technology. The value proposition to our customers was compelling, and the market finally embraced our efforts. We recognized a long time ago that eventually, other contractors would build AC rigs to compete with H&P. We often get the question, "Are you concerned about your peers' new AC drive rigs?" We answer that by saying, "Our strategy has remained focused: build the best rigs, employ the best people and create support systems and processes that continue to deliver the FlexRig value proposition to our customers." 
The future holds many opportunities for H&P. The FlexRig3, FlexRig4 and FlexRig5 makeup approximately 37% of the AC drive market share in the U.S. today, and FlexRigs have an opportunity to take market share internationally as well. 
Before turning the call back to Juan Pablo, let me mention a key element of our company culture. Our focus on continuous improvement and building a learning organization is a key advantage in both the highs and lows of the energy cycle. I am proud of what our people accomplished in 2014 for our customers, where we drilled over 71 million feet of wellbore and operated over 325 rigs at the peak of activity in October of last year. 
In addition to setting records for footage and rig activity, our people continue to work on innovative technology solutions, safety systems, cost control systems and processes that position the company to be better prepared today than ever before and certainly better than we were in the 2009 downturn. 
The organization's response to this very severe reduction in rig count has been significant. Our field operations to date have idled over 150 rigs, taking care to preserve the rig and equipment integrity so we are ready to respond when the market improves. I believe our experienced leadership team provides us with an advantage to manage through the current downturn even more efficiently and effectively than during previous cycles. 
And let me close by saying equally important to the tactical side of our business is our continued strategic focus on organizational effectiveness during these difficult times. We will continue to invest in systems and processes, which will allow us to efficiently scale operations to meet changing industry conditions and be prepared with our significant AC fleet capability to respond quickly to future demand levels. We believe this makes H&P the best position drilling contractor in the industry today. 
Now I'll turn the call to Juan Pablo, and he'll give you more details on the second fiscal quarter and the outlook for next quarter. Juan Pablo?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. The company reported $150 million in net income, $227 million in operating income and $883 million in revenues during the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Given the steep downturn that the industry is experiencing, these quarterly levels we
componenttext:
Thank you, John. The company reported $150 million in net income, $227 million in operating income and $883 million in revenues during the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Given the steep downturn that the industry is experiencing, these quarterly levels were down significantly as compared to the prior quarter and are expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter. 
Following are some comments on each of our drilling segments. Our U.S. land drilling operations delivered approximately $225 million in segment operating income during the second fiscal quarter. As expected, the number of quarterly revenue days significantly declined, resulting in an average of approximately 231 active rigs during the second fiscal quarter, representing a 24% decline in revenue days as compared to the first fiscal quarter. On average, approximately 158 of these rigs were under term contract and approximately 73 rigs work in the spot market. 
Excluding the impact of early termination revenues, the average rig revenue per day decreased by 3.6% to $27,575, and the average rig expense per day increased by 2.7% to $13,395, resulting in an average rig margin per day of $14,180. 
During the quarter, the segment generated approximately $71 million in revenues corresponding to long-term contract early terminations. Given existing notifications for early terminations, we expect to generate over $75 million during the third fiscal quarter and over $30 million after that in early termination revenues. 
Just November of last year, we have received termination notices for a total of 44 rigs under long-term contracts in the segment. 
Total early termination revenues related to these 44 contracts are now estimated at approximately $204 million, approximately $90 million of which corresponds to cash flow previously expected to be generated through normal operations during fiscal 2015, $65 million during fiscal 2016 and $49 million after that. 
As of today, the 336 available rigs in the U.S. land segment include approximately 165 AC drive FlexRigs generating revenue and 171 idle rigs, including 163 idle AC drive FlexRigs. 
Included in the 165 rigs generating revenue are 138 rigs under term contracts and 27 rigs in the spot market. The 165 rigs generating revenue include rigs that are on standby-type day rate and some new build deliveries that have been delayed in exchange for compensation from customers. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter of fiscal 2015, we expect revenue days to  decrease by about 32% quarter-to-quarter and given the current trend, we could have approximately 150 rigs or less generating revenue days by the end of the quarter. 
Excluding the impact of revenues corresponding to early terminated long-term contracts, we expect our average rig revenue per day to decline to roughly $27,000. The average rig expense per day is expected at roughly $13,600. 
Subject to additional early terminations and excluding rigs that we have received early termination notifications for, the segment already have term contract commitments in place for an average of approximately 130 rigs during the third fiscal quarter, an average of about 117 rigs during the fourth fiscal quarter and an average of about 107 rigs and 79 rigs during fiscal 2016 and fiscal 2017 respectively. 
The average rig margin per day levels for these rigs that are already under term contracts is expected to remain strong and roughly flat during the next several quarters, as some rigs roll-off and new builds are deployed. 
The pricing for rigs in the spot market declined by approximately 15% from the first to the second quarter of fiscal 2015 and is expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter. Spot pricing today is about 23% lower as compared to spot pricing at the peak last November. 
Let me now transition to our offshore segment. Segment operating income declined to approximately  $19 million from $21 million during the prior quarter. Total revenue days decreased by about 2%, as one rig was demobilized and became idle during the second fiscal quarter. 
The average rig margin per day declined by about 10% to $18,671 during the second fiscal quarter, as one rig that continues to generate revenue while stacked on the customer's platform had a significant day rate and margin reduction. 8 of the company's 9 offshore platform rigs continue to generate revenue days by the end of the second fiscal quarter. 
As we look at the third quarter of fiscal 2015, we expect revenue days to decline by about 10%, as 1 of the 8 rigs generating revenue completes its current project, is demobilized and becomes idle during the quarter. We also expect the average rig margin per day to decline to approximately $12,000 during the quarter. The expected average rig margin decline is mostly attributable to 3 rigs that are generating revenue days during the third fiscal quarter but that are now expected to be idled on the corresponding customer offshore platforms with new day rates and margins that are significantly lower as compared to regular operating day rates and margins. 
A total of 7 of the company's 9 offshore platform rigs are now expected to be generating revenue days at the end of the third fiscal quarter. 
Management contracts on platform rigs continued to favorably contribute to our offshore segment operating income. Their contribution during the second fiscal quarter was approximately $8 million and is expected to decline to approximately $6 million during the third fiscal quarter. 
Moving on to our international land operations. Segment operating income decreased to approximately $6 million during the quarter. Excluding the impact of $373 per day corresponding to early contract termination revenues, the average rig margin per day slightly decreased to $10,524. As expected, quarterly revenue days decreased by about 11% to an equivalent of slightly over 20 active rigs. 
As of today, our international land segment has 21 active rigs, including 12 in Argentina, 4 in Colombia, 2 in the UAE, 2 in Ecuador and 1 in Bahrain. 17 rigs are idle, including 3 that are under contract but no longer active. These 17 rigs include 5 in Argentina, 4 in Ecuador, 4 in Colombia, 2 in Bahrain and 2 in Tunisia. An additional 2 rigs are mobilizing to fill locations in Argentina.
For the third fiscal quarter, we expect international land quarterly revenue days to be flat, potentially increasing up to 5%. We expect the average rig margin per day to decline by about 15% to 20% as compared to the second fiscal quarter, excluding any impact from early contract terminations. We expect to generate early termination revenues in this segment of approximately $9 million during the third fiscal quarter and another $9 million during the fourth fiscal quarter, corresponding to 2 rigs that are under contract but no longer active.
The expected daily margin decline in the segment is primarily due to rigs that are in transition and others becoming idle. We expect to see all 10 of the YPF project rigs generating revenue days during the fourth fiscal quarter. 
Let me now comment on corporate-level details. Our liquidity position is very long. We recently issued 10-year unsecured notes for $500 million with 4.65% coupons and a 4.723% yield. Our capital expenditures estimate for fiscal 2015 remains at approximately $1.3 billion, about 70% of which corresponds to the funding of our continued organic growth under the sponsorship of attractive long-term contracts with customers. Our fiscal 2015 construction cadence remains unchanged, but we are reducing our fiscal 2016 cadence to one FlexRig per month beginning in October through March ,which allows us to have greater new builds continuity as we go through this downturn, while at the same time not impacting the corresponding value of our backlog. 
Including the long-term contracts for the 40 new FlexRigs scheduled to be delivered during all of fiscal 2015 and the additional 6 rigs scheduled for fiscal 2016, we have secured term contracts for an average of approximately 148 rigs across our 3 drilling segments during the third fiscal quarter, and approximately 134 rigs during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2015. In addition, an average of about 121 rigs is already under contract during fiscal 2016 and an average of approximately 93 rigs during fiscal 2017.
The term contract coverage just mentioned excludes long-term contracts for which we have received early contract termination notifications. Given that these early terminations allow us to remain whole in terms of our expected cash flow from the corresponding operations, their impact on both our earnings and liquidity should be favorable as this accelerates the expected payback on our investments. 
Given the trends in market conditions, our backlog decreased from approximately $4.6 billion as of December 31, 2014, to approximately $3.9 billion as of March 31, 2015. The value of our backlog is expected to continue to decline during the third fiscal quarter as we earn related income through operations or through early contract terminations. 
We expect our total annual depreciation expense to be approximately $600 million during fiscal 2015, and our general and administrative expenses to be approximately $140 million. Interest expense after capitalized interest is expected to be approximately $15 million for fiscal 2015, and the effective tax rate for the remaining 2 quarters of fiscal 2015 is expected to be between 34% and 35%. Our deferred income tax liability as of March 31, 2015, was approximately $1.32 billion. 
At this point, we expect this liability to remain in the range of $1.3 billion and $1.4 billion through at least the end of fiscal 2017.
With that, let me turn the call back to John.

componenttext:
Thank you, Juan Pablo. Now before opening the call to questions, I want to reiterate a few key points. As we manage through the current decline in activity, our fleet size provides us with a distinct advantage. With the largest AC drive fleet available in the industry today, the company has unprecedented leverage to significantly increase activity levels during the future industry recovery and ongoing replacement cycle. 
In addition to our fleet advantage, H&P has over 1,600 rig years of AC drive experience. This experience provides the foundation to deliver superior value to our customers by providing innovative solutions and safer, more productive operations. We expect these efforts, along with the company's demonstrated capital discipline, to continue to result in pricing, margin and return on investment premiums that allow us to create value for our shareholders. 
And now we will open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, Kurt, this is John. The Flex 1s and 2s, and I think you recognized the [indiscernible], but the Flex 1s and 2s were SCR rigs. They were also rigs that we didn't design the structures on the rig. They were bought through the kind of the traditional s
componenttext: Well, Kurt, this is John. The Flex 1s and 2s, and I think you recognized the [indiscernible], but the Flex 1s and 2s were SCR rigs. They were also rigs that we didn't design the structures on the rig. They were bought through the kind of the traditional sourcing in the marketplace. Those rigs haven't worked really last couple of years. We have had some different opportunities to potentially sell those rigs. But really, the Flex 3s, 4s and 5s,  the Flex 3s that we built in 2002 to 2004, if you recall the first 32 we built, those rigs have continued to work their both spot and term, and they've been in a situation where they typically commanded the same type of revenues and margins that we've seen with our newer Flex 3s. Some have skid systems and some don't. It's kind of a mixed bag. But I feel real good about where we are in terms of drilling with those rigs going forward. We do have, I just wanted to remind you, too, we do have 8 3,000 horsepower SCR rigs, one of which we work at the end of last year on the deep project, deep gas project in South Louisiana. We'll continue to have those rigs. We have 2,000 and 3,000 horsepower SCR rigs working in South America. And then, of course, we have our first 3,000 horsepower AC rig also working in South America, working in Colombia. So I feel good about where we are. And I think those rigs that we've continued to upgrade those rigs over time and just about every way possible, they continue to deliver great value for customers, and I feel good about where we are with those rigs.

componenttext: Great. How do you -- a lot of questions on many fronts here about, hey, we have the first time where we're going to a cycle downturn with significant excess capacity in Tier 1 rigs. What is it going to look like coming out on the other side, prospects of those rigs, maybe not finding work? How do you assess coming out the other side secular [ph] recovery? And given the excess capacity in Tier 1 land rigs, how would you expect pricing to behave in this cycle versus maybe what you experienced back in 2012, 2013?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, today is a different market than what we saw in 2012 and 2013. Today is obviously a lot more similar to the downturn at the end of '08 and going into '09, first part of 2010. Of course, as you said, we -- I think we have 15% of the active f
componenttext: Well, clearly, today is a different market than what we saw in 2012 and 2013. Today is obviously a lot more similar to the downturn at the end of '08 and going into '09, first part of 2010. Of course, as you said, we -- I think we have 15% of the active fleet at the peak in '08 that was AC drive. So it is going to be a different environment. It's hard to say exactly where pricing will be. I think our expectation would be in the spot market, similar to what we saw in '09, were in the high teens range. The rigs that we're going to be competing against, there will still be some head-to-head competition with AC on AC. But you still have a significant number of SCR and mechanical rigs that are out working today, drilling unconventional resource plays but really are designed to adequately address the challenges and deliver to tough cycle times that an AC rig can deliver.

componenttextpreview: Well, Angie, I think we've -- this isn't the first significant downturn we've been through. I just mentioned the '08, '09 downturn, and we responded coming out of that very well. I think our peak rig count in '08 was about 185, and we got down to a little
componenttext: Well, Angie, I think we've -- this isn't the first significant downturn we've been through. I just mentioned the '08, '09 downturn, and we responded coming out of that very well. I think our peak rig count in '08 was about 185, and we got down to a little over 100 rigs. And, of course, this time, we're -- we got close to 300 rigs working in the U.S. and we're down to 160. Our experience is that the rigs go back to work. We have a lot of experienced, skilled personnel on the rigs that are working and, in a lot of cases, lower positions, so those guys are always eager to move up into that next role, that next slot. And I personally don't think it's going to be a challenge. The other advantage that we have in our business, of course, is that when you compare the earnings that a guy can have working a year in oilfield compared to building houses or other types of competitive jobs, there's really not a great comparison. And so I think people are typically eager to come back. And I think with H&P specifically, we could -- have created a lot of job opportunities and upward mobility, and our guys have seen that through the cycles. We've grown more quickly than our peers. And when we have that kind of growth, we promote from within, and those guys have opportunities to move up in the organization. So that's a long-winded answer to your question, but I don't think we're going to have a challenge personally

componenttext: That's very helpful. And then, Juan Pablo, this probably a question for you, and I've had the question asked to me. So given the current market environment, how much of a focus is the dividend, the commitment to the dividend going forward? Obviously, you have more liquidity. You just did the debt offering. So just comments there and your thoughts going forward.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Angie. We've said in the past that every time the company looks at the possibility of increasing dividends, as we have of course over the last few years, especially the sustainability of that dollar per share amount is a very important consideration
componenttext: Sure, Angie. We've said in the past that every time the company looks at the possibility of increasing dividends, as we have of course over the last few years, especially the sustainability of that dollar per share amount is a very important consideration. And we look at different scenarios and stress cases to determine whether or not we feel comfortable with the sustainability of those new levels. And we certainly do feel comfortable and continue to feel comfortable that we will be in good position to continue to pay those dividends for the foreseeable future. And potentially, hopefully, as the industry and the market recovers, we might have a situation where we, once again, increase it. Of course, there may be situations in the mid- to long term that are unexpected, that may be extreme, that may represent a structural change in the business, that we might have to look at and determine whether at that point there may be a change. But as far as we can see, we are very comfortable with the sustainability and our commitment to dividend.

componenttext: John, I wanted to go back to your -- one of your earlier statements about you said, recently, you put some AC drive rigs in the spot market that have replaced older rigs. So the kind of high grading process that you were predicting has -- seems to be starting to happen. So I wonder if you could talk about the rate that -- of the rig that you're replacing. Are you getting a higher rate? And is the value proposition still there in this kind of market environment on newly signed contracts?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robin. The rigs that we have replaced are, in some cases, legacy rigs. In other cases, I think they're -- in one of the cases, it was kind of a lower end performing AC rig. And the day rates that we received -- I know in the legacy rig case, it was a
componenttext: Yes, Robin. The rigs that we have replaced are, in some cases, legacy rigs. In other cases, I think they're -- in one of the cases, it was kind of a lower end performing AC rig. And the day rates that we received -- I know in the legacy rig case, it was a higher rate. I'm assuming it was on the other rig as well. They were high-teens type rate is kind of what we've talked about. The value proposition is clearly there. I mean, you've seen our value proposition slide that we've shown for years, where we're saving 10%, 15%, 20% on a well. We have a higher day rate, and we're able to save the customer money as well as deliver more wells in a given year by working that rig. So our belief continues to be that there will be a replacement cycle -- the replacement cycle will continue. However, again, I stated, too, just a handful of rigs. Unfortunately, we still have more rigs becoming idle than rigs that we're putting back into the market. But it at least -- at least it is an encouraging sign that we haven't seen in a couple of months, anyway.

componenttext: Yes, right. So one of your latest presentations shows the AC drive market share at about 51%. So as we get to the bottom of the market, would still be at around that percentage? And it still leaves a large number of rigs to be displaced ultimately by the Tier 1 rigs. So do you see that, these very early signs that you've noted? Are there more people interested? You're talking about people interested -- you're talking to more people interested in doing that as we get to the bottom of the market and perhaps stabilize somewhere at that level?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That would be our expectation, Robin. I think the AC drive market share today in the current active fleet is approximately 54%. So it's up slightly from what you quoted from the previous presentation. I think it will probably continue to increase. And wha
componenttext: That would be our expectation, Robin. I think the AC drive market share today in the current active fleet is approximately 54%. So it's up slightly from what you quoted from the previous presentation. I think it will probably continue to increase. And what you'll see over time, of course, is that as older --  because there are some older rigs, legacy rigs and then underperforming rigs that are on term contract, that as they roll off, there's possibility that those rigs could be high graded. So that would be our expectation. That's what we saw in 2009 and 2010. Our customers, operators in general, looking for an opportunity. The other advantage to this type of a market is the ability to attract new customers. In 2009 and 2010, we were able to attract a lot of new customers to H&P because they didn't have to sign a 3-year term contract. They didn't have to wait in line. They were able to grab an available FlexRig and put it to work and test drive it and see how it worked out. Another data point is in the horizontal and directional market, AC rigs have approximately 59% market share. So again, you can just see that there's another large percentage of rigs that are mechanical and SCR rigs that are drilling horizontal and directional that are drilling some pretty challenging complex wells. So that offers a great upside for us.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kind of want to stick with this, the thought of value proposition and looking a little longer term. But John, is there a scenario where maybe some less competitive rigs stick around because operators choose them? Because on price, for example, if those ri
componenttext: Kind of want to stick with this, the thought of value proposition and looking a little longer term. But John, is there a scenario where maybe some less competitive rigs stick around because operators choose them? Because on price, for example, if those rigs are going for $12,000 a day and an AC type rig is going for $18,000 to $20,000 a day, is that $6,000 gap there in the day rate, is that enough to sway an operator to stick with the less competitive rig? Do you have a sense of that?

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Dave, our experience would tell us that if the operator is sticking with that lower tier rig, they're giving up some value because, again, we've heard this from many customers -- or pardon me, many competitors over the years, that when -- as they be
componenttext: Well, Dave, our experience would tell us that if the operator is sticking with that lower tier rig, they're giving up some value because, again, we've heard this from many customers -- or pardon me, many competitors over the years, that when -- as they began to get the picture that they needed a more advanced rig to compete in the market place, oftentimes, they would say, and these were leaders within their organization would say, "We can't charge a rate low enough that is compelling for an operator to pick that rig up because of the value proposition." So we believe that it's clear that it's there. It doesn't mean that we're implying that there won't ever be or there won't be mechanical and SCR rigs working in the future. I think that there will be, but I do think it's going to be a fewer number. We've talked about it on our last call, you can go back and review the notes, I'm not going to try to recap it, but with each successive peak and trough, it was each successive cycle you see fewer and fewer mechanical and SCR rigs kind of dating back to 2005, and that trend will continue. One of the components in addition to customers that's important, and I didn't touch on this earlier when Angie asked a question about people, and that is the new rigs, AC drive FlexRigs, are so much better to work on. They're safer. They're more environmentally conducive to working on. It's just an easier work environment. And so -- and that has a real attraction to people. So you're going to  get the best people that are going to be working on the newer rigs, which puts a lot of pressure again on rigs that were designed in 70 -- 60, 70s and 80s.

componenttext: I'd like to get your opinion on the macro outlook here over the next 6 to 12 months. Just kind of look beyond the trough, which appears to be nearing. We've heard some from some other industry participants this morning, John, unwillingness to call an inflection point at least in the second half of the year. But as I think about it, I take your 800 or so trough number of rigs working in the U.S. which seemed reasonable. The peak-to-trough drop of about 60%, this actually appears on par, if not an excess of the drop in E&P cash flow. And more importantly, the E&Ps have adjusted their activity levels to the improvement in spending power that's come through the system. I've realized this takes time, but why doesn't this happen in the second half of the year? Should we expect -- do you expect a decent rebound in activity before year-end, call it 100-plus rigs, once we've cleared what I assume is a modest backlog of uncompleted wells? Just thinking through the impact of this improvement in spending power, and certainly, the capital markets are open to the E&Ps. So just interested of your outlook on rebound potential before year-end.

headline: Helmerich & Payne, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Scott this is John. I -- thank goodness, I don't get paid to make predictions on oil and gas prices. But our sense is, like we talked about in our opening comments, our sense is it feels like we're finding a floor. As you know, there are so many var
componenttext: Well, Scott this is John. I -- thank goodness, I don't get paid to make predictions on oil and gas prices. But our sense is, like we talked about in our opening comments, our sense is it feels like we're finding a floor. As you know, there are so many variables involved and things that are -- that could -- that are  unexpected that could happen, which is why I think, again, we continue to see our customers being cautious. But you're right, we said, we talked about on our last call that markets work, and eventually they work and oil prices have a tendency to overshoot on the high side, the low side. There's a lot of forces working out there that could potentially contribute to exactly what you said. And so I think your reasoning is right on target, it's just a very difficult situation to try to call it. I think there are a lot of people out there now that seem to be leaning more towards the second half of the year, in the first part of 2016 and starting to see some improvement. And so I think that's a reasonable assumption, but I sure don't want to try to call it.

componenttext: Scott, we've talked about that, talked about it a lot over time. And you've heard us talk about one of the key advantages that we have as a company is our fleet uniformity and standardization of practices and supply chain, training, those types of things. And I think at least for H&P, it would be somewhat dilutive for us to go out and acquire a competitor. And again, we thought through it, whether it's a small competitor or large. In any event, it ends up having a dilutive effect. We would prefer to continue to grow the company organically. We see some real synergies associated with having the fleet that we have, and that's part of what we're speaking to as we talk about processes and systems as we move forward. So -- but does it make sense from an industry perspective? I think it does. I think there's probably some logical combinations out there. I don't know who it would be, but I'm sure there's some logical opportunities.

You think your sense -- you talked about how spot pricing has fallen, you've talked -- you've mentioned high teens and you're placing some rigs there. componenttextpreview: Brad, I think you've heard us, you probably heard us comment before we talked about in the last call that there really isn't --  there really hasn't been a spot market per se. We're starting to see a little bit of a spot market develop now. I mean, obviou
componenttext: Brad, I think you've heard us, you probably heard us comment before we talked about in the last call that there really isn't --  there really hasn't been a spot market per se. We're starting to see a little bit of a spot market develop now. I mean, obviously, it's going to come down to competitors deciding at what level they're going to price rigs at. I think for us right now, we're down -- I think Juan Pablo said we're down 23% spot pricing. To remind you, in '09, 2009, spot pricing was down approximately 30% from the peak. So we've kind of thought that 30% was a reasonable type of an estimate. I'm not --  I don't think we can call a bottom on spot market pricing at this stage of the game because I think we're still really early in on developing the spot market. However, I will say, I think, an interesting point to keep in mind is that while we have 30% market share on the AC, our next 3 largest peers have approximately 38%. So 75% is -- of the market share of AC is by 4 contractors and then there's approximately 20 that make up the next, the other 25%. So it's a relatively small group of competitors out there, and so you would think there would be some pricing discipline. I know I've heard some of our larger peers talk about that and being willing to defend a certain level of pricing. So that would be our expectation going forward, but it's -- I don't think we're in a position where we can call the trough on spot market pricing.

componenttextpreview: Well, we've actually had Flex 3s deploy internationally with skid systems. And so we have Flex 3s working internationally both with and without skid systems. It's really -- I would say it's a demand pull basis. Not all customers are doing pad drilling. An
componenttext: Well, we've actually had Flex 3s deploy internationally with skid systems. And so we have Flex 3s working internationally both with and without skid systems. It's really -- I would say it's a demand pull basis. Not all customers are doing pad drilling. And so it's just going to be a function of as customers transition from single well pads or -- and going into a more multi-well pad layout, then that's when we add the skid system to the rig. And those customers want to keep the rig, and they want to keep the folks together and they get the skid system to go along with it.

componenttext: Mid-March. Okay, so mid-March, we had 31 early terminations. And I think I even commented on the last call that we were surprised of the ones that we have received. At the same time, as we began to kind of think about it a little bit, you contrast with the number of early terminations that we have in 2008 and 2009, we had close to 40. And at that time, we had, like I said earlier, a working rig fleet of about 185. At this time, we're closer to 300, and we're at 44. So it doesn't feel like it's really out of balance that the early terminations in general have been less than a year left on the term contract. So on a percentage basis, it's --  I don't think it's out of touch. I think it really just gets to -- down to the bottom at the end of it.  At the end of the day, we've got customers that just have more rigs on term than they can handle with their budgets, and the lowest-cost alternative for them is to early terminate the rig. And really, think about  it, it's a fairly low-cost option to get out from underneath that forward spend, and I think that's how a lot of the customers have looked at it. Have excess to the best rigs and then when they get into that situation, they just early terminate the rig. So I don't --  I'm not overly concerned by it. I am surprised, however, that it has gotten to that level, but as I started thinking about it, contrasting it, it's a lower percentage than what we saw. I think it's less than 15%, and back in '09 and 2010, it was over 20% of our fleet.
